I will admit bias towards this style of beer but the flip side of that is that this is one of the few beers that truly changes depending on how it is served. Whether it be bottled,on tap or on a nitro tap, it seems to evolve. My favorite method is on Nitro which for me isnt a common thing to say, but if you find a place that has a keg of this on nitro,sit down and be ready to be surprised. 

It comes out a dark amber colour and holds a commendable amount of carbonation for a style that is typically known to go flat fast, the pour methods previously mentioned seem to extend both the time and bring out subtleties in the brew that otherwise seem to lost from the bottle.

From the bottle it seems to be smooth yet consistently sharp as it finishes in terms of palate, which if consumed with a good pairing or used in cooking a meal like a beef stew with a sour dough bread bowl (something I have done often), can be very rewarding.

Considering its potential to be bitter,it seems very balanced, healthy amount of malt,carbonation,smooth taste,sharp finish,tendency to lace well and over all holds a profile that lends itself to be either consumed directly or used in cooking year round. Next experiment will be to use it for beer battered fried chicken.

 Taste  The taste begins much drier then I would have anticipated from the nose, starting with just a hint of caramel sweetness mixed with a rather stronger roasted bready taste. As the taste advances the caramel upfront fades away with a light dark fruity flavor taking its place. At the same time some hop flavors of a grassy and floral hop taste mixed with a little bit of graininess come to the tongue and with a light earthy hop coming at the very end, one is left with a rather dry and roasty taste to linger on the tongue.

April 15th, 2012 - Scottish Ales dont seem like promising beers for the San Diego beerscape. Its sweet, not hoppy, dark, not light, and probably makes a surly companion on a hot day. But that didnt stop Ballast Point from attempting to graft San Diegan beer culture onto the style. The product of this cross-cultural brewing begins with a wet and clean nose, delivering a smooth malt profile, and the wet, shaggy sprouted malt that defines the aroma of a brewery on a brew day. Most noticeable on the tongue is the absence of the peat and deep, malty sugars that tend to define Scotch ales for me. The flavor profile is still very distinctive though, featuring a heavy, substantial palate, thats just weighty enough to balance against a busy carbonation. The malt taste is crystal clear and poignant, semisweet, and extremely drinkable. The complexity between the shades of sweet, sugar and graininess is underwhelming, and the total absence of hops or any balancing astringency doesnt help. Perhaps, in the effort to use ab abundance of UK-centric ingredients, the potential for something a little deeper was sacrificed, but its still an interesting riff on the Scotch Ale style.

Flavor is more earthy toasted malts which turns into nice mellow and tangy caramel sweetness.  There is a light hop bitterness in the finish.  Seems light and not very complex for the style.
Served cold from tap at brewery. My girlfriend thought it was quite hoppy, but the flavor was a bit more on the malty side with some good caramel and nutty notes.
(Draught)  Pours a deep amber body with a medium beige head.  Aroma of caramel, grass, grain, peat, and dark fruits.  Flavor of nuts, caramel malt, fruit, light smoke, and grain.
On ta at Beachwood BBQ. Dark brown with foamy beige head. Malty aroma, with astringent bitter hops. Flavor is dark malts, almost meaty, with a nice crispness.

On tap at Beachwood BBQ. Pours with a huge, rocky tan head with a ruby brown body beneath. Aroma of smoke, chocolate, dark fruits, butterscotch and tobacco. Taste is creamy caramel, light butterscotch, tobacco, some esters, bitterness and burnt brown sugar. Syrupy mouthfeel and light bubbles.

Draft at the brewery. An amber beer with a thin white head. The aroma has notes of malt, caramel, and lemon. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, citrus, and alcohol. A mixture of Scotland and San Diego.

On tap from the Linda Vista location: Poured in a full 4oz serving with a thin foamy head and a caramel brown color. Aroma was reminiscent of their Navigator doppelbock with a caramel malt or toffee based scent. The flavor was refined and smooth with a thick malt backbone and nice toasted flavor that really impresses me compared to the other American made Scottish ales I have tasted in the last few years.
Pours a nice brown carmel color.  Earthy and very smooth, but nothing very notable or over done.  Very drinkable without being too memorable.

Growler from Ballast Point Linda Vista.  Poured a brownish-amber with a medium sized light brown head.  Aroma wasn’t too great; earthy, caramel, wood and nuts.  Flavor was better; earthy, peaty-smoked malt, caramel and fruit.  A really nice and pretty soft palate.  Pretty solid, but nothing in comparison to the barrel aged version which was delicious.
Had at San Diego Brewers Guild Festival 2008. Pours a cloudy brown. Licorice, cider on the nose. Cider and whiskey flavors with some nicely placed vanilla. Smooth mouth. Tasty.

Pours a light brown color, with a medium light brown head.  Smells of some dark malts and dark fruits mixed.  Overall mild aroma.  Nice balance to the flavor.  Some caramel malt and dark fruits, apples, and grapes mostly.  A touch of some woodsyness in the finish to go along with the fruity sweetness left on the palate.  Decent little scottish ale, but nothing to go nuts for.

On tap at Ballast Point during the RBSG Pub Crawl Tour on 08/01/2008. Clear copper amber body with a medium off-white head. Sweet nutty caramel aroma. Sweet caramel nutty flavor. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

Draft... RBSG 08...  Beautiful, crystal clear, copper ale with a small, creamy, white head. Decent retention. The subtle aroma is of caramel; nothing more, nothing less. Medium-bodied and slightly creamy with subdued carbonation. Sways just a tad toward the bitter side of balance. Finishes caramelly, then bitter.

Draft. Rich amber beer with a dark cream-colored head. Big caramel malt aroma. malt, caramel flavor with light citrus and earth. Medium bodied. Caramel lingers with a bit of citrus. I expected more of a stone fruit, but I got light citrus. Hmm...

Sampled from growler @ brewery, RBSG.  Clear amber pour with a thick khaki head.  Mostly caramel malts on the nose, mild earthy hop background.  Nice fruity malt characters on the taste, subtle hop finish.  A nice Scottish.

RBSG 2008. Pours amber with a tall light tan head. Smooth and balanced, with warm caramel malt base. I didn’t pick up much smokiness in this, and they said it was modeled after Belhaven’s scottish which has a lot more smokiness. Smooth and drinkable, but a smoky finish would have done wonders.
BRSG08.  Pours red/amber with dim. head.  Dry, light fruit aroma.  Sweet flavors smooth out the finish well.  Mellow mouthfeel.

Sampled from a growler at the brewery for RBSG 08. Pours a clear amber-brown, with a thick, off-white head. Sweet malty aroma, with dark fruit and smoke notes. Taste is clean and a little sweet, of malt, dark fruits, and caramel. Lingering sweet malt flavors. Tasty Scottish ale.

Sampled at Ballast Point, RBSG ’08 - poured by one of the brewers (nice guy) out of a growler. Pours an attractive, clear bronze with an off-white head. Bread, caramel and noble hops in the nose; subtle but nice. Like the aroma, the flavor follows with notes of toffee, earth, bread, grass and a light herbal quality. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Scottish ales aren’t really my thing but this one was well-made and quite enjoyable.

RBSG:    Growler @ production facility.  Poured a clear mahogany color with a beige head.  The aroma had a light sweetness with plenty of caramel malt.  Hints of fruit, chocolate and smoke.  The flavor also had plenty of caramel malt sweetness.  A little more smoke notes to the flavor.  Medium bodied.

Growler at Ballast Point.  Poured clear, rich caramel with a creamy, well-retained cap of beige head.  The aroma picked up sweet toasty caramel with just a faint hint of smoke.. well-presented.  The flavor was sweeter, yet still dry with a hint of toffee and nutmeg along with the caramel.. drier finish with more lightly-smoked caramel.. tasty.  Medium-bodied and dry overall with a light smoky finish.  Good one.

From tap at the brewery. Pours clear and golden hazzlenut brown with a lacing white head. Dense caramel and breadish malt aroma. Flavour is breadish and light hops bitter with a light spiced note. Ends dry and breadish malty. Nice and easy.
From a Growler Craig Poured at RBSG at the main Brewery.  Overall malty and interesting.  A decent scottish needs a bit more bite for me.

Sample at the Linda Vista location. This brew is a clear brownish-amber color with a thin light beige head that diminishes slowly. Thin rings of lacing on the glass. The aroma has a bit of a smoked character, and notes of earthy malt and caramel. Medium, smooth body with toasted malt, caramel and dark fruit flavors. Bits of chocolate and hops as well. The finish is roasty and sweet with a toasted malt aftertaste. Pretty good overall.

On tap @ Coronado brewery.  Pours a mostly clear brown with a faint red tint.  Nose had hints of herbal hops, nuts, caramel and toasted malt, flavor was much of the same.  Not as full bodied as I was expecting, very drinkable, nice.

On-tap at HomeBrew Mart. Pours brown/red with a pillowy offwhite head, good lace. Smells sweet and malty, slightly sour. Tastes malty and caramelly sweet. Pretty deep complex, sweet malt flavors, very nice. Medium body, nice carbonation.

Tap at the 11th anniversary.  Deep golden-orange brown with a small tan head.  Sweet tangy malt aromatics, some chocolate.  Alefruit, toasty/nutty malt flavors up front.  Rich rasiny, chocolate characters then manifest.  Spicy, eartthen hop component in the finish with residual bittersweet chocolate and a hint of smokiness.  Mouthfeel is a heavy medium, somewhat chewy.

on tap at ballast points anniv party
well, it looks like a scottish ale...
it was bland, not terribly malty. not what Id expect

On tap @ Ballast Point (Linda Vista) - Pours a reddish-brown color with a small light tan head.  Thin lacing.  Aroma and flavor is sweet caramel malt with a faint hint of smoke and peat.  Light to medium body.  A decent beer.
Red in color smell of malt with sweet taste. dry finish with a hint of caramel notes. pretty good beer.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2007 08/01/07: Tried on tap at the brewery.  Grains are $1.59/lb there.  I think that is a good price.  22 IBUs.  Nice creamy 1 finger head.  Dark brown-black color.  Nice above average scottish ale, kind of stoutist.  A nice hair towards the sweet side.  Subdued roasted grains.7/4/7/3/16:3.7

10/21/07: 6/4/6/3/13:3.2 Tried at Ballast Points 11th anniversary party.  A little bland and not sweet. Common brown ale

Pours with an opaque dark brown body topped by a thin to medium thick, off-white head with some lacing. Its sweet and malty with a note of fruit, caramel, and a bit of roastiness.  Medium to full bodied, bubbly and oily.
Pours a deep bown amber hue with a slight off-white head.  Aromas of caramel, toffee, a little vanilla. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with flavors of cola, hints of cherries, and some hints of caramel.
On tap a Obriens.  I would have to say Cherry Coke like apperaance.  The aroma was subtle, however there was some malt and yeast.  Flavors were somewhat disappointing, watered down malt and yeast.

Draft at OBriens.  Cola like appearance.  Color, head and effervescence were 100% Pepsi-like.  Aromas were roasty malts with some caramel and earthy tones.  Flavors were more roasted and some slightly smoky flavors.  Decent.

On tap at Hamiltons. Classic 80 Schilling / Export Scottish Ale.  Clean aroma with no ale yeast esters (low fermentation temp?).  Roasty, caramel aroma with small bubbles.  I thought that the color was a little dark.  When held to a light the candy cane red comes through (long boil?).  Brilliant clarity.  Balanced flavor.  Low bitterness but a dryness from a roasted grain. No peat flavors though. Malty aftertaste lingers.  A great session ale.  Wheres my NY Steak and sauteed mushrooms?
On tap at Ballast Point.  Clear reddish brown with a creamy off-white head.  Roasty caramel aroma.  Taste of caramel, roastiness, and a slightly nutty flavor with a fairly clean finish.
